seg.seg: One blames the one who sits in silence, [45a] Sanskrit one blames (the one who speaks much), [45b]
Man tadelt [wtl. sie tadeln] den, der schweigend sitzt, (man) tadelt (den, der viel spricht, man tadelt den, der wenig spricht:) Es gibt niemanden in der Welt, der nicht getadelt wird.
They scold him who sits in silence, (they) scold (him who speaks much, they scold him who speaks little:) there is no one in the world that is not scolded.
Sanskrit there is no one irreproachable in the world. [45d]
Sanskrit Or the one (who is) exclusively praised, [46b] Sanskrit
(Einen Menschen, der nur getadelt) oder nur gelobt [wird], (gab es nicht, wird es nicht geben und) gibt es auch jetzt (nicht).
(A human, who [is] scolded only) or praised only, (does not exist, will not exist and) now (does not) exist either.
and presently no such one is even found. [46d] Sanskrit But the one whom (the wise ones praise), [47a]
Sanskrit that praise has been said (definitely). [47c] Sanskrit
The one provided with wisdom, characterized by (good) behavior, [48a] Sanskrit the wise one (...) [48b]
Einen Einsichtigen, einen mit (dem ]guten] Wandel) Verbundenen, einen Verständigen, ..., wer kann den tadeln?
A reasonable one, one connected to (the [good] conduct), a prudent one, ... who can reproach such a one?
like (a coin of gold), [48c] Sanskrit who is entitled to blame that one? [48d] Sanskrit
it (= the mountain) does not tremble (because of the wind), [49b] Sanskrit in the very same way by blame (or praise), [49c]
Sanskrit At the basis of which there is no root, [50a] Sanskrit
such a wise one liberated from all chains, [50c] Sanskrit who (is entitled to blame that one?)
Sanskrit who has turned away from continuity and the abyss, [51b]
Sanskrit the world even with its gods does not recognize (him). [51d] Sanskrit

p.note: The edition is based on autopsy of the original manuscript.

The mutilated akṣara at the beginning of the line belongs to Skt. āsīnaṃ (45a). In the middle of the line the reading nandanti is certain instead of nindanti. This mistake may be due to the influence of the TB match naksenträ.

As match of the locative plural Skt. lokeṣu (45d) one finds the locative singular TB śaiṣṣene ‘in the world’. One may surmise the omission of an anusvāra in the form śaiṣṣeṃne, but the singular also makes perfect sense.
The first word has to be restored as Skt. nāsti (45d).
The adverb Skt. ekāntaṃ ‘absolutely, exclusively’ (46b) has been translated according to the etymological meaning ‘having a unique goal’, i.e., TB somo-kälymi ‘having a unique direction’.
The complete translation of the pāda 46d na cāpy etarhi vidyate can be safely restored as mā ra no ñake kälpāsträ.
The first visible akṣara belongs to Skt. praśaṃsā (47c).The last visible syllable belongs to yaḥ (47d).

The Sanskrit compound vṛtta-yuktam (48a) lit. ‘provided with good conduct’, ‘virtuous’ has been translated etymologically by TB yakne ‘way, manner’ and the PPt of the verb ritt(ā)- ‘to be attached, linked to’. As for the match of Skt. medhāvin- ‘provided with wisdom’ a likely candidate would be TB pälskossu (TA pälskasu) ‘provided with thinking’.

There is no trace of virāma after ‹nta›. This final group -ssont belongs to the oblique singular masculine of an adjective in -ssu translating Skt. medhāvinaṃ (45a). At the end of the line a part of the uppermost paper layer has been torn away before ai. This syllable certainly begins the word aiśaumye translating Skt. prājñaṃ (48b).
The first visible sequence is the end of TB ramt translating Skt. iva (48c). The last visible syllable on the line begins Skt. śailo (49e).

As translation of the compound Skt. nindā-praśaṃsā- ‘blame and praise’ we may expect a TB coordinative sequence nākälyñe pālalyñe, since pālalñe is already recorded as translating Skt. praśaṃsā- in [[SI B 14]] a6.
One may restore the complete translation of the pāda 49b Skt. vāyunā na prakampyate as wentesa mā waskanträ.
Again a case of literal translation: Skt. kṣiti- in this passage means ‘basis, foundation’ but it has been understood as meaning ‘earth’.

Note that the same device for noting final Skt. -m as seen elsewhere in this manuscript is even found in the parallel TA fragment a3: /// nān muktam\ • cam\ ///. Interestingly, the anaphoric demonstrative pronoun TB cau is matched by TA cam.
At the beginning of the line one reads the end of Skt. muktam. Note that the final nasal is noted in the same way in a1 and probably in a6.

The Sanskrit text edited by Bernhard has saṃtānaṃ parikhaṃ ca (51b) “continuity and ditch”, which has been literary translated into Tocharian. To be sure, this does not make much sense. Therefore, one may assume that the original wording underwent corruption from a Middle Indic original that contained the nouns saṃdāna- ‘chain’ and parigha- ‘barrier’, see 406 who translates the stanza as: “der von den Hindernissen und den Fesseln frei geworden ist [who has become free from the hindrances and the bonds]” (p. 115). Note that the TA translator did not try to transpose saṃtāna- and simply used the loan word santāṃ ( a4), probably because the TA match sark had adopted the meaning ‘line of descendants, descent’.
The line begins with the final part of Skt. santānaṃ (51b). At the end of the line one should restore TB kaklautkau translating Skt. nivṛttaḥ.
For the translation of the pāda 51d the fragment a5 reads: /// naṣ śla ñä(kc)iṃ ///. Accordingly, it can be restored by comparison with the TB text as: (mā knā)naṣ śla-ñä(kc)iṃ (penu ārkiśoṣi).
